Body found on Route 128

Police said the victim was apparently struck crossing the highway in Newton. An investigation is ongoing and traffic is delayed in both directions. (Globe, 8:29 a.m.)

DiMasi claims he never received bribe

Lawyers for Sal DiMasi said in court papers filed this week that the former Mass. house speaker was wrongly convicted of corruption in 2011, arguing that he did not accept bribes as federal prosecutors contend. (Globe)

Opinion | Dan Shaughnessy

Celtics headed for a fall

They don't play defense, are weak on the offensive glass, lack toughness, they’re lost when Kevin Garnett is not on the court, and some guys don't seem to care.

Social programs more vulnerable

The lack of spending cuts in legislation that averted the fiscal cliff will place enormous pressure on Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, and the new heath insurance plan.
Opinion | Joan Vennochi

Mass. Democrats for democracy?

Democrats want to clear a path for Edward Markey in his bid to replace John Kerry in the Senate, although a primary battle could be good for the party and its nominee.

Departures at South Boston
charter school raise concerns

During the inaugural year of UP Academy, the in-district charter school, 19 percent of its students left, a rate slightly lower than the average for Boston middle schools.

Tax credit boosts wind industry

The fiscal cliff deal includes a key change that will make it easier for wind ­developers to obtain what are viewed as crucial incentives for a burgeoning industry.
Opinion | Juliette Kayyem

A storm of a fight

The delay in providing Congressional aid to victims of Hurricane Sandy also delays an upgrade to the federal relief system.

Boston Baroque sparkles

On New Year's Eve, bubbly and sparkly is what people want, and bubbly and sparkly is what they got.
